meta.dc:subject: legislation
meta.dc:rights: the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

longTitle.name: longTitle
longTitle.content: To prohibit false trade descriptions, false, misleading or incomplete information, false marks and misstatements in respect of goods provided in the course of trade or suppliers of such goods; to confer power to require information or instruction relating to goods to be marked on or to accompany the goods or to be included in advertisements; to restate the law relating to forgery of trade marks; to prohibit certain unfair trade practices; to prohibit false trade descriptions in respect of services supplied by traders; to confer power to require any services to be accompanied by information or instruction relating to the services or an advertisement of any services to contain or refer to information relating to the services; and for purposes connected therewith.

section.name: s1
section.heading: Short title
section.content: This Ordinance may be cited as the Trade Descriptions Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: In this Ordinance, unless the context otherwise requires—
subsection.def: advertisement (宣傳品) includes a catalogue, a circular and a price list;
authorized officer (獲授權人員) means a public officer appointed under section 14;
average consumer (一般消費者)—see section 13D; (Added 25 of 2012 s. 3)

commercial practice (營業行為) means any act, omission, course of conduct, representation or commercial communication (including advertising and marketing) by a trader which is directly connected with the promotion of a product to consumers or the sale or supply of a product to or from consumers, whether occurring before, during or after a commercial transaction (if any) in relation to a product; (Added 25 of 2012 s. 3)
Commissioner (關長) means the Commissioner of Customs and Excise and any Deputy or Assistant Commissioner of Customs and Excise; (Added L.N. 294 of 1982. Amended 65 of 2000 s. 3)
Communications Authority (通訊事務管理局) means the Communications Authority established by section 3 of the Communications Authority Ordinance (Cap. 616); (Added 25 of 2012 s. 24)

consumer (消費者) means an individual who, in relation to a commercial practice, is acting, or purporting to act, primarily for purposes that are unrelated to the person’s trade or business; (Added 25 of 2012 s. 3)
Convention country (公約國家) means a Paris Convention country or WTO member as defined in section 2(1) of the Trade Marks Ordinance (Cap. 559); (Replaced 35 of 2000 s. 98)
exempt person (獲豁免人士) means a person who is acting in the capacity of a person described in an item of Schedule 3; (Added 25 of 2012 s. 3)

def.name: FalseTradeDescription
def.leadIn: false trade description (虛假商品說明) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a trade description which is false to a material degree; or (Amended 25 of 2012 s. 3)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a trade description which, though not false, is misleading, that is to say, likely to be taken for a trade description of a kind that would be false to a material degree; (Amended 25 of 2012 s. 3)

subsection.def: forged trade mark (偽造商標) has the meaning assigned to it by section 9(3); (Added 35 of 2000 s. 98)
goods (貨品) includes vessel and aircraft, things attached to land and growing crops;

def.name: GoodsInTransit
def.leadIn: goods in transit (過境貨品) means goods which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: are brought into Hong Kong on a vessel or aircraft for the sole purpose of taking them out of Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: remain at all times while they are in Hong Kong on the vessel or aircraft; (Replaced 19 of 2008 s. 4)

subsection.def: import (進口) means to bring, or cause to be brought, into Hong Kong;

def.name: InfringingGoods
def.leadIn: infringing goods (侵犯權利貨品) means goods to which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a forged trade mark is applied; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a trade mark or mark so nearly resembling a trade mark as to be calculated to deceive is falsely applied; (Added 35 of 2000 s. 98)

subsection.def: invitation to purchase (購買邀請) means a commercial communication that indicates characteristics of the product and its price in a way appropriate to the medium used for that communication and therefore enables the consumer to make a purchase; (Added 25 of 2012 s. 3)
mark (標記), when used as a noun, includes a sign capable of distinguishing the goods of one undertaking from those of other undertakings; (Added 35 of 2000 s. 98)
premises (處所) includes any place and any stall, vehicle, vessel or aircraft;
product (產品) means any goods or service but does not include any goods or service covered by Schedule 4;
Secretary (局長) means the Secretary for Commerce and Economic Development; (Added 5 of 2012 s. 3)

service (服務) includes any right, benefit, privilege or facility that is, or is to be, provided, granted, conferred or offered under a contractual right other than one arising under a contract of employment as defined by section 2(1) of the Employment Ordinance (Cap. 57); (Added 25 of 2012 s. 3)

def.name: TradeDescription
def.leadIn: trade description (商品說明), in relation to goods, means an indication, direct or indirect, and by whatever means given, with respect to the goods or any part of the goods including an indication of any of the following matters— (Amended 25 of 2012 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: quantity (which includes length, width, height, area, volume, capacity, weight and number), size or gauge;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: method of manufacture, production, processing or reconditioning;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: composition;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: fitness for purpose, strength, performance, behaviour or accuracy;

paragraph.name: ea
paragraph.content: availability; (Added 25 of 2012 s. 3)

paragraph.name: eb
paragraph.content: compliance with a standard specified or recognized by any person; (Added 25 of 2012 s. 3)

paragraph.name: ec
paragraph.content: price, how price is calculated or the existence of any price advantage or discount; (Added 25 of 2012 s. 3)

paragraph.name: ed
paragraph.content: liability to pay duty on them under the laws of Hong Kong, generally or in specified circumstances; (Added 25 of 2012 s. 3)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: testing by any person and results thereof;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: approval by any person or conformity with a type approved by any person;

paragraph.name: ga
paragraph.content: a person by whom they have been acquired, or who has agreed to acquire them; (Added 25 of 2012 s. 3)

paragraph.name: gb
paragraph.content: their being of the same kind as goods supplied to a person; (Added 25 of 2012 s. 3)

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: place or date of manufacture, production, processing or reconditioning;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: person by whom manufactured, produced, processed or reconditioned;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: other history, including previous ownership or use;

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.leadIn: availability in a particular place of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a service for the inspection, repair or maintenance of the goods; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: spare parts for the goods; (Added 19 of 2008 s. 4)

paragraph.name: l
paragraph.content: warranty given in respect of the service or spare parts referred to in paragraph (k); (Added 19 of 2008 s. 4)

paragraph.name: m
paragraph.content: the person by whom the service or spare parts referred to in paragraph (k) are provided; (Added 19 of 2008 s. 4)

paragraph.name: n
paragraph.content: the scope of the service referred to in paragraph (k)(i); (Added 19 of 2008 s. 4)

paragraph.name: o
paragraph.content: the period for which the service or spare parts referred to in paragraph (k) are available; (Added 19 of 2008 s. 4)

paragraph.name: p
paragraph.content: the charge or cost at which the service or spare parts referred to in paragraph (k) are available; (Added 19 of 2008 s. 4)

def.name: TradeDescription
def.leadIn: trade description (商品說明), in relation to a service, means an indication, direct or indirect, and by whatever means given, with respect to the service or any part of the service including an indication of any of the following matters—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: nature, scope, quantity (including the number of occasions on which, and the length of time for which, the service is supplied or to be supplied), standard, quality, value or grade;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: fitness for purpose, strength, performance, effectiveness, benefits or risks;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: method and procedure by which, manner in which, and location at which, the service is supplied or to be supplied;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: availability;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: testing by any person and the results of the testing;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: approval by any person or conformity with a type approved by any person;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: a person by whom it has been acquired, or who has agreed to acquire it;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: the person by whom the service is supplied or to be supplied;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: after-sale service assistance concerning the service;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: price, how price is calculated or the existence of any price advantage or discount; (Added 25 of 2012 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a trade mark relating to goods registered or deemed to be registered in Hong Kong under the Trade Marks Ordinance (Cap. 559);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a certification mark or collective mark relating to goods registered or deemed to be registered in Hong Kong under the Trade Marks Ordinance (Cap. 559);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: a trade mark—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: registered in a Convention country; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: capable of registration in Hong Kong under the Trade Marks Ordinance (Cap. 559) as a trade mark relating to goods;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: a trade mark—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in respect of which an application for registration has been made in a Convention country; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: capable of registration in Hong Kong under the Trade Marks Ordinance (Cap. 559) as a trade mark relating to goods; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: in respect of which a period of 6 months has not expired since the date of the application for the registration thereof in a Convention country; (Replaced 35 of 2000 s. 98. Amended 25 of 2012 s. 3)

subsection.def: trader (商戶) means any person (other than an exempt person) who, in relation to a commercial practice, is acting, or purporting to act, for purposes relating to the person’s trade or business;

def.name: TransactionalDecision
def.leadIn: transactional decision (交易決定) means any decision made by a consumer, whether it is to act or to refrain from acting, concerning—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether, how or on what terms to purchase, make payment in whole or in part for, retain or dispose of a product; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whether, how or on what terms to exercise a contractual right in relation to a product. (Added 25 of 2012 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance, goods shall be deemed to have been—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: manufactured in the place in which they last underwent a treatment or process which changed permanently and substantially the shape, nature, form or utility of the basic materials used in their manufacture; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: produced in the place in which they were wholly grown or mined.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: The Commissioner may by order specify— (Amended L.N. 294 of 1982)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in relation to any description of goods, what treatment or process is to be regarded for the purposes of this Ordinance as resulting or not resulting in a permanent and substantial change in shape, nature, form or utility of the basic materials used in their manufacture;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in relation to any description of goods different parts of which were manufactured or produced in different places, or of goods assembled in a place different from that in which their parts were manufactured or produced, in which of those places the goods are to be regarded for the purposes of this Ordinance as having been manufactured or produced. [cf. 1968 c. 29 s. 36 U.K.]

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: This subsection shall not apply to goods which are the subject of a notice published under subsection (2A). (Added 96 of 1991 s. 2. Amended 9 of 2005 s. 2)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: The Director-General of Trade and Industry may by notice in the Gazette specify in relation to any description of goods (being goods that are subject to a scheme of import or export control specified in the notice) the place in which the goods are to be regarded for the purposes of this Ordinance as having been manufactured or produced, and any such goods shall, for the purposes of this Ordinance, be deemed to have been manufactured or produced in such place. (Added 96 of 1991 s. 2. Amended L.N. 173 of 2000)

subsection.name: 2B
subsection.content: Subsections (2) and (2A) do not apply to specified goods, as defined in section 2A(1), that are covered by section 2A(3). (Added 5 of 2012 s. 3)

For the purposes of this Ordinance, a trade description or statement published in any newspaper, book or periodical or in any film or sound or television broadcast shall not be deemed to be a trade description applied or statement made in the course of a trade or business unless it is or forms part of an advertisement. [cf. 1968 c. 29 s. 39(2) U.K.]
To avoid doubt, immovable property is itself not a product (because it is not goods) while a service supplied in relation to immovable property may be a product. (Added 25 of 2012 s. 3)
In this Ordinance a reference to a trader includes any person acting in the name of, or on behalf of, a trader. (Added 25 of 2012 s. 3)
A note located in the text of this Ordinance is provided for information only and has no legislative effect. (Added 25 of 2012 s. 3)

section.name: s2A
section.heading: Special provisions for place of manufacture or production under certain trade agreements or arrangements

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: date of entry into force (生效日期), in relation to a trading partner place under a scheduled trade arrangement, means the date specified in column 4 of Schedule 1 corresponding to the place and the arrangement;
scheduled trade arrangement (表列貿易安排) means a regional or international trade agreement or arrangement specified in column 2 of Schedule 1;

def.name: SpecifiedGoods
def.leadIn: specified goods (指明貨品), in relation to a trading partner place under a scheduled trade arrangement, means any goods that are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: qualified for preferential tariff treatment, as between the place and Hong Kong, under the arrangement; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to rules, specified in the arrangement, for determining the place of manufacture or production of the goods;

subsection.def: trading partner place (貿易夥伴地), in relation to a scheduled trade arrangement, means a place to which the arrangement is applicable, other than Hong Kong, specified in column 3 of Schedule 1 corresponding to the arrangement.

def.name: RulesOfOrigin
def.leadIn: The rules referred to in paragraph (b) of the definition of specified goods in subsection (1) (rules of origin) may be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: rules based principally on—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the place in which the goods last underwent a treatment or process which changed permanently and substantially the shape, nature, form or utility of the basic materials used in their manufacture; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the place in which the goods were wholly grown or mined;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: rules based principally on—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a maximum percentage of the value of the goods attributable to places other than Hong Kong or a trading partner place under the relevant scheduled trade arrangement; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a minimum percentage of the value of the goods attributable to Hong Kong or a trading partner place under the relevant scheduled trade arrangement;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: rules of a kind described in paragraph (a)(i) or (ii) or (b)(i) or (ii) or any combination, with or without modifications; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any other rules.

subsection.leadIn: In relation to a trading partner place under a scheduled trade arrangement for the time being in force as between the place and Hong Kong, if, on or after the relevant date of entry into force, any specified goods are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: exported or intended to be exported to the place in accordance with the arrangement; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: imported from the place in accordance with the arrangement,

subsection.continued: then the rules of origin for the goods, specified in the arrangement for the time being in force as between the place and Hong Kong, apply for the purpose of determining the place of manufacture or production of the goods under this Ordinance.

subsection.content: The Secretary may by notice published in the Gazette amend Schedule 1.
The Director-General of Trade and Industry is to make available at his or her office all scheduled trade arrangements for inspection, free of charge, by the public during normal office hours.

Notwithstanding the definition of false trade description in section 2, a trade description which indicates the fineness (whether in parts per thousand or in carats) of gold shall be a false trade description if that indication is false to any extent or degree, except by understating the fineness. (Amended 5 of 2012 s. 5) [cf. 1973 c. 43 s. 1(4) U.K.]

subsection.leadIn: For the purpose of construing descriptions relating to the fineness of gold—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a description indicating that an article, or the metal in an article, is so many carats shall be presumed to be an indication that the article or metal is of gold, and that its fineness is that specified in the table in Schedule 1A for that number of carats; (Amended 19 of 2008 s. 5; 5 of 2012 s. 5)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: paragraph (a) shall not apply if (as in a case where the article is a precious stone) the word “carat” is used as a measure of weight for precious stones, and not as a measure of fineness. [cf. 1973 c. 43 Sch. 1 U.K.]

subsection.leadIn: Notwithstanding the definition of false trade description in section 2—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a trade description which indicates that any article (other than an article of pure gold) is of gold shall be a false trade description unless the article consists solely of gold alloy and—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: contains not less than 8 carats of gold; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: bears a mark clearly indicating in carats, by number or by number and the letters “k”, “c” or “ct”, the fineness of the gold content; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: bears a mark clearly indicating in parts per thousand the fineness of the gold content; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a mark calculated to be taken as an indication of the fineness of gold of an article—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: which is plated with or enclosed in gold alloy or gilded; or (Amended L.N. 272 of 1990)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to which gold alloy is soldered or otherwise affixed,

paragraph.continued: shall be a false trade description unless it is manifest from the appearance of the article that the mark refers solely to the part of the article which consists of gold alloy.

subsection.content: Any number of 1 or 2 digits on an article which indicates or purports to indicate, or is likely to be taken as an indication of, the fineness in carats of its gold content shall be a false trade description unless the article contains at least the same proportion of pure gold as the number bears to 24.

Any number of 3 digits on an article which indicates or purports to indicate, or is likely to be taken as an indication of, the fineness in number of parts per thousand of its gold content shall be a false trade description unless the article contains gold of such a standard of fineness.

subsection.def: For the purposes of this section fineness (純度) means the proportion of pure gold in accordance with subsection (4) or the number of parts by weight of gold in accordance with subsection (5) as the case may require.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Marking and provision of information, etc. orders

subsection.content: The Chief Executive in Council may by order require that any goods specified in the order must be marked with or accompanied by any information, or that any services specified in the order must be accompanied by any information, (whether or not amounting to or including a trade description) or instruction relating to the goods or services and, subject to the provisions of this Ordinance, impose requirements for securing that the goods or services are so marked or accompanied, and regulate or prohibit the supply of goods or services with respect to which the requirements are not complied with; and the requirements may extend to the form and manner in which the information or instruction is to be given. (Amended 65 of 2000 s. 3)

Where an order under this section is in force with respect to goods or services of any description, any person who, in the course of any trade or business, supplies or offers to supply goods of that description in contravention of the order, or any trader who supplies or offers to supply services of that description to a consumer in contravention of the order, commits an offence. (Amended L.N. 272 of 1990)

An order under this section may make different provision for different circumstances and may, in the case of goods supplied in circumstances where the information or instruction required by the order would not be conveyed until after delivery, require the whole or part thereof to be also displayed near the goods. (Amended 25 of 2012 s. 33)

Without prejudice to subsection (2), an order under this section may provide that a contravention of any provision of the order is an offence punishable with a fine at level 6 and a term of imprisonment for 3 months. (Added 19 of 2008 s. 6)

For the avoidance of doubt, information required by 2 or more orders made under subsection (1) to be contained in an invoice or receipt may, where the information is provided in respect of the same item of goods or the same kind of service, be contained in one single invoice or receipt. (Added 19 of 2008 s. 6)

section.name: s5
section.heading: Information to be given in advertisements

subsection.content: The Chief Executive in Council may by order require that any description of advertisements of any goods or services specified in the order shall contain or refer to information (whether or not amounting to or including a trade description) relating to such goods or services and subject to the provisions of this Ordinance impose requirements as to the inclusion of that information or of an indication of the means by which it may be obtained. (Amended 65 of 2000 s. 3)

An order under this section may specify the form and manner in which any such information or indication is to be included in advertisements of any description and may make different provision for different circumstances.

Where an advertisement of any goods to be supplied in the course of any trade or business, or of any services to be supplied by a trader to a consumer, fails to comply with any requirement imposed under this section, any person who publishes the advertisement commits an offence.

part.name: P2
part.heading: False Trade Descriptions or Representations and Forged Trade Marks

section.name: s6
section.heading: Applying a trade description, trade mark or mark to goods

subsection.leadIn: A person applies a trade description or trade mark or mark to goods if he—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: affixes or annexes it to or in any manner marks it on or incorporates it with—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the goods themselves; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: anything in, on or with which the goods are supplied;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: places the goods in, on or with anything which the trade description or trade mark or mark has been affixed or annexed to, marked on or incorporated with, or places any such thing with the goods;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: uses the trade description or trade mark or mark in any manner likely to be taken as referring to the goods; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: makes in any affidavit, declaration or writing any statement to the effect that a trade description or trade mark or mark is applicable to the goods.

subsection.content: An oral statement may amount to the use of a trade description or trade mark or mark.

Where goods are supplied in pursuance of a request in which a trade description or trade mark or mark is used and the circumstances are such as to make it reasonable to infer that the goods are supplied as goods corresponding to that trade description or trade mark or mark, the person supplying the goods shall be deemed to have applied that trade description or trade mark or mark to the goods.

section.name: s6A
section.heading: Applying a trade description to services

subsection.leadIn: A person is to be regarded as applying a trade description to a service if the person gives (by whatever means and whether direct or indirect) an indication of any kind with respect to the service or any part of the service including—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where the indication is given in such a manner that it is likely to be taken as referring to the service; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the person makes in any affidavit, declaration or writing a statement to the effect that the indication is applicable to the service.

subsection.content: An oral statement may amount to the use of a trade description.

If a service is supplied in response to a request in which a trade description is used and the circumstances are such as to make it reasonable to infer that the service is supplied as a service corresponding to that trade description, the person supplying the service is to be regarded as having applied that trade description to the service.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Offences in respect of trade descriptions of goods

subsection.leadIn: Subject to the provisions of this Ordinance, any person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in the course of any trade or business—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: applies a false trade description to any goods; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: supplies or offers to supply any goods to which a false trade description is applied; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has in his possession for sale or for any purpose of trade or manufacture any goods to which a false trade description is applied,

subsection.content: A person exposing goods for supply or having goods in his possession for supply shall be deemed to offer to supply them.

Subject to the provisions of this Ordinance any person who disposes of or has in his possession any die, block, machine, or other instrument for the purpose of making, or applying to goods a false trade description commits an offence unless he proves that he acted without intent to defraud. (Amended L.N. 272 of 1990)

section.name: s7A
section.heading: Offences in respect of trade description of services

subsection.leadIn: A trader who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: applies a false trade description to a service supplied or offered to be supplied to a consumer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: supplies or offers to supply to a consumer a service to which a false trade description is applied,

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: service (服務) does not include any service covered by Schedule 4.

subsection.content: The following provisions of this section shall have effect where in an advertisement a trade description is used in relation to any class of goods or services.

subsection.leadIn: The trade description is to be taken as referring to all goods or services of the class, whether or not in existence at the time the advertisement is published—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the purpose of determining whether an offence has been committed under section 7(1)(a)(i) or 7A(1)(a); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where goods or services of the class are supplied or offered to be supplied by a person publishing or displaying the advertisement, also for the purpose of determining whether an offence has been committed under section 7(1)(a)(ii) or 7A(1)(b). (Replaced 25 of 2012 s. 9)

subsection.content: In determining for the purposes of this section whether any goods or services are of a class to which a trade description used in an advertisement relates, regard shall be had not only to the form and content of the advertisement but also to the time, place, manner and frequency of its publication and all other matters making it likely or unlikely that a person to whom the goods or services are supplied would think of the goods or services as belonging to the class in relation to which the trade description is used in the advertisement.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Offences in respect of trade marks

subsection.leadIn: Subject to the provisions of this Ordinance, any person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: forges any trade mark;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: falsely applies to any goods any trade mark or any mark so nearly resembling a trade mark as to be calculated to deceive;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: makes any die, block, machine or other instrument for the purpose of forging, or of being used for forging, a trade mark;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: disposes of or has in his possession any die, block, machine or other instrument for the purpose of forging a trade mark; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: causes to be done anything referred to in paragraph (a), (b), (c) or (d),

subsection.continued: commits an offence unless he proves that he acted without intent to defraud.

subsection.content: Subject to the provisions of this Ordinance, any person who sells or exposes or has in his possession for sale or for any purpose of trade or manufacture, any goods to which any forged trade mark is applied, or to which any trade mark or mark so nearly resembling a trade mark as to be calculated to deceive is falsely applied, commits an offence.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this section but subject to subsection (3A), a person shall be deemed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: to forge a trade mark who either—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: without the consent of the owner of the trade mark, makes that trade mark or a mark so nearly resembling that trade mark as to be calculated to deceive; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: falsifies any genuine trade mark, whether by alteration, addition, effacement or otherwise;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: falsely to apply to goods a trade mark who without the consent of the owner of that trade mark applies that trade mark to goods,

subsection.continued: and forged trade mark (偽造商標) shall be construed accordingly. (Replaced 35 of 2000 s. 98)

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.leadIn: A person shall not be deemed under subsection (3) to forge a trade mark, or falsely to apply to goods a trade mark, if the person proves—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that he acted without infringing any right of the owner of the trade mark conferred by the Trade Marks Ordinance (Cap. 559);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the trade mark or mark was not used by him in the course of any trade or business as a trade mark in relation to goods;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that the use made by him of the trade mark or mark is not a use in relation to goods for which the trade mark is registered and is not a use in relation to goods similar to those for which it is registered; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: that the use made by him of the trade mark or mark is a use to which the rights of the owner of the trade mark do not extend by reason of a disclaimer, limitation or condition to which the trade mark is subject. (Added 35 of 2000 s. 98)

subsection.content: In any prosecution for an offence under subsection (1)(a) or (b) the burden of proving the consent of the owner shall lie on the defendant. (Amended 35 of 2000 s. 98)

section.name: s12
section.heading: Prohibited import and export of certain goods

subsection.content: A person must not import or export any goods to which a false trade description or forged trade mark is applied. (Amended 35 of 2000 s. 98; 25 of 2012 s. 10)
Any person who imports or exports any goods contrary to subsection (1) commits an offence. (Amended 18 of 2014 s. 52)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.leadIn: Without limiting section 26, in any proceedings for an offence under this section, the person charged is entitled to be acquitted—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: if—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: sufficient evidence is adduced to raise an issue that the person charged—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: did not know;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: had no reason to suspect; and

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: could not with reasonable diligence have ascertained,

subparagraph.continued: that the goods are goods to which a false trade description or forged trade mark is applied; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the contrary is not proved by the prosecution beyond reasonable doubt; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the person charged proves that the goods are not intended for trade or business. (Added 18 of 2014 s. 52)

subsection.content: This section shall not apply to any goods in transit.

In determining the effect on the average consumer of a commercial practice that reaches or is directed to a consumer or consumers, account must be taken of the material characteristics of such an average consumer including that the consumer is reasonably well informed, reasonably observant and circumspect.

In determining the effect on the average consumer of a commercial practice in the circumstances specified in subsection (3), a reference to the average consumer is a reference to the average member of the particular group of consumers.

subsection.leadIn: For the purpose of subsection (2) the circumstances are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where the commercial practice is directed to a particular group of consumers; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: where—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a clearly identifiable group of consumers is particularly vulnerable to the commercial practice or the underlying product because of mental or physical infirmity, age or credulity in a way which the trader could reasonably be expected to foresee; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the practice is likely to cause the average member of that group only to make a transactional decision that the member would not have made otherwise.

subsection.content: Subsection (3)(b) does not prejudice the common and legitimate advertising practice of making exaggerated statements which are not meant to be taken literally.
A trader who engages in relation to a consumer in a commercial practice that is a misleading omission commits an offence.

subsection.leadIn: A commercial practice is a misleading omission if, in its factual context, taking account of the matters in subsection (3)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it omits material information;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it hides material information;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: it provides material information in a manner that is unclear, unintelligible, ambiguous or untimely; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: it fails to identify its commercial intent, unless this is already apparent from the context,

subsection.continued: and as a result it causes, or is likely to cause, the average consumer to make a transactional decision that the consumer would not have made otherwise.

subsection.leadIn: The matters referred to in subsection (2) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: all the features and circumstances of the commercial practice;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the limitations of the medium used to communicate the commercial practice (including limitations of space or time); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the medium used to communicate the commercial practice imposes limitations of space or time, any measures taken by the trader to make the information available to consumers by other means.

subsection.leadIn: If a commercial practice is an invitation to purchase, the following information is material, if not already apparent from the context—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the main characteristics of the product, to the extent appropriate to the product and to the medium by which the invitation to purchase is communicated;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the identity (such as trading name) of the trader and of any other trader on whose behalf the trader is acting;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the address (not including a postal box address) of the trader’s usual place of business and of any other trader on whose behalf the trader is acting;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: either—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the price, including any taxes; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if the nature of the product is such that the price cannot reasonably be calculated in advance, the manner in which the price is calculated;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: where appropriate, either—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: all additional freight, delivery or postal charges; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if those charges cannot reasonably be calculated in advance, the fact that they may be payable;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.leadIn: the following matters if they depart from the requirements of professional diligence—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: arrangements for payment;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: arrangements for delivery of goods;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: arrangements for supply of service;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: for products in relation to which there is a right of withdrawal or cancellation, the existence of that right.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to a commercial practice that is an invitation to purchase, any information that is material as a result of subsection (4); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in every case—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the information that the average consumer needs, according to the context, to make an informed transactional decision; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any other information required in relation to a commercial communication under any other enactment;

def.name: ProfessionalDiligence
def.leadIn: professional diligence (專業勤勉) means the standard of skill and care that a trader may reasonably be expected to exercise towards consumers which is commensurate with either—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: honest market practice in the trader’s field of activity; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the general principle of good faith in that field.

subsection.content: A trader who engages in relation to a consumer in a commercial practice that is aggressive commits an offence.

subsection.leadIn: A commercial practice is aggressive if, in its factual context, taking account of all of its features and circumstances—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it significantly impairs or is likely significantly to impair the average consumer’s freedom of choice or conduct in relation to the product concerned through the use of harassment, coercion or undue influence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it therefore causes or is likely to cause the consumer to make a transactional decision that the consumer would not have made otherwise.

subsection.leadIn: In determining whether a commercial practice uses harassment, coercion or undue influence, account must be taken of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: its timing, location, nature or persistence;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the use of threatening or abusive language or behaviour;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the exploitation by the trader of any specific misfortune or circumstance, of which the trader is aware and which is of such gravity as to impair the consumer’s judgement, to influence the consumer’s decision with regard to the product;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any onerous or disproportionate non-contractual barrier imposed by the trader where a consumer wishes to exercise rights under the contract, including rights to terminate the contract or to switch to another product or another trader; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: any threat to take any action which cannot legally be taken.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: coercion (威迫) includes the use of physical force;

undue influence (不當影響) means exploiting a position of power in relation to the consumer so as to apply pressure, even without using or threatening to use physical force, in a way which significantly impairs the consumer’s ability to make an informed decision.

subsection.content: A trader who engages in relation to a consumer in a commercial practice that constitutes bait advertising commits an offence.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (3), advertising by a trader of products for supply at a specified price is bait advertising if there are no reasonable grounds for believing that the trader will be able to offer for supply those products at that price, or the trader fails to offer those products for supply at that price, for a period that is, and in quantities that are, reasonable, having regard to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the nature of the market in which the trader carries on business; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the nature of the advertisement.

subsection.leadIn: Advertising by a trader of products for supply at a specified price is not bait advertising if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the advertisement states clearly the period for which, or the quantities in which, the products are offered for supply at that price; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the trader offers those products for supply at that price for that period or in those quantities.

subsection.content: A trader who engages in relation to a consumer in a commercial practice that constitutes a bait and switch commits an offence.

subsection.leadIn: The making by a trader of an invitation to purchase a product at a specified price is a bait and switch if, having made the invitation, the trader then, with the intention of promoting a different product—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: refuses to show or demonstrate the product to consumers;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: refuses to take orders for the product or deliver it within a reasonable time; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: shows or demonstrates a defective sample of the product.

subsection.content: A trader who engages in relation to a consumer in a commercial practice that constitutes wrongly accepting payment for a product commits an offence.

subsection.leadIn: A trader wrongly accepts payment for a product if the trader accepts payment or other consideration for the product and at the time of that acceptance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the trader intends not to supply the product;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the trader intends to supply a product that is materially different from the product in respect of which the payment or other consideration is accepted; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: there are no reasonable grounds for believing that the trader will be able to supply the product—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: within the period specified by the trader at or before the time at which the payment or other consideration is accepted; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if no period is specified at or before that time, within a reasonable period.

subsection.content: The Commissioner may appoint any public officer to be an authorized officer for the purposes of this Ordinance.
The Commissioner may exercise any of the powers conferred on an authorized officer under this Ordinance.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Power to enter premises and inspect and seize goods and documents

subsection.leadIn: An authorized officer may, on production, if required, of evidence of his appointment—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: make such purchases of goods as may appear expedient for the purpose of determining whether or not the provisions of this Ordinance are being complied with;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the purpose of ascertaining whether any offence under this Ordinance has been or is being committed, inspect any goods and enter any premises other than domestic premises;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if he has reasonable cause to suspect that an offence under this Ordinance has been committed, seize or detain any goods for the purpose of ascertaining, by testing or otherwise, whether the offence has been committed;

paragraph.name: ca
paragraph.content: for the purpose of ascertaining whether any offence under this Ordinance has been or is being committed, require any person carrying on a trade or business or employed in connection with a trade or business to produce any books or documents required to be kept under this Ordinance and may take copies of, or of any entry in, any such book or document; (Added 25 of 2012 s. 25)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: if he has reasonable cause to suspect that an offence under this Ordinance has been committed and for the purpose of ascertaining whether it has been committed, require any person carrying on a trade or business or employed in connection with a trade or business to produce any books or documents relating to the trade or business and may take copies of, or of any entry in, any such book or document;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of any premises, vehicle, vessel (other than a ship of war) or aircraft (other than a military aircraft) in which he has reasonable cause to suspect that there are goods in respect of which an offence under this Ordinance has been or is being committed—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: subject to section 16, enter and search such premises;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: stop and search such vehicle; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: stop, board and search such vessel or aircraft;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.leadIn: seize, remove or detain—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any goods in respect of which he has reasonable cause to suspect an offence under this Ordinance has been or is being committed; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: anything which he has reason to believe may be required as evidence in proceedings for an offence under this Ordinance.

subsection.statutoryNote:
Note—
By virtue of section 3 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1) a reference to an Ordinance includes subsidiary legislation made under it, unless the contrary intention appears. (Added 25 of 2012 s. 25)

subsection.leadIn: An authorized officer may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: break open any container or open any vending machine for the purpose of exercising his powers under subsection (1)(f) to seize goods;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: break open any outer or inner door of any place which he is empowered or authorized by or under this Ordinance to enter and search;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: forcibly board any vessel or aircraft which he is empowered by this Ordinance to stop, board or search;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: remove by force any person or thing obstructing him in the exercise of any power conferred on him by this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: detain any person found in any premises which he is empowered or authorized by or under this Ordinance to search until such place has been so searched;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: detain any vessel or aircraft which he is empowered by this Ordinance to stop, board and search, and prevent any person from approaching or boarding such vessel or aircraft until it has been so searched;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: detain any vehicle which he is empowered by or under this Ordinance to stop and search until it has been so searched.

section.name: s16
section.heading: Restrictions on the entry and search of domestic premises

subsection.leadIn: No domestic premises shall be entered and searched by an authorized officer unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a magistrate has issued a warrant under subsection (2); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Commissioner has given an authorization under subsection (3). (Amended L.N. 294 of 1982)

subsection.content: A magistrate may, if he is satisfied by information on oath that there is reasonable ground for suspecting that there is in any domestic premises any goods or thing which may be seized, removed or detained under section 15(1)(f), issue a warrant authorizing an authorized officer to enter and search the premises.

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner may, if he is satisfied that there is reasonable ground for suspecting— (Amended L.N. 294 of 1982)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that there is in any domestic premises any goods or thing which may be seized, removed or detained under section 15(1)(f); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that unless the premises are entered and searched immediately such goods or thing are likely to be removed from the premises,

subsection.continued: authorize in writing an authorized officer to enter and search the premises.

subsection.content: An authorized officer authorized under subsection (2) or (3) to enter and search any domestic premises may take with him such other persons and such equipment as may appear to him to be necessary.

section.name: s16A
section.heading: Power to detain goods by locking or sealing premises or container

subsection.leadIn: An authorized officer may, for the purpose of detaining, under section 15—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any goods in respect of which he has reasonable cause to suspect that an offence under this Ordinance has been or is being committed; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: anything which he has reason to believe may be required as evidence in proceedings for an offence under this Ordinance,

subsection.continued: place a lock or seal on any premises or container in which the goods or things are.

subsection.content: If a lock or seal is placed on any premises or container under subsection (1), the period for which the lock or seal is placed shall not exceed 7 days without the consent in writing of the owner of the premises or container, or his authorized agent.

subsection.leadIn: If an authorized officer has placed a lock or seal on any premises or container under subsection (1), any person who breaks or interferes with such lock or seal commits an offence unless he does so—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in the bona fide belief that it is necessary immediately to break or interfere with the lock or seal in order to prevent—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: injury being suffered by any person; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: damage being incurred to any such premises or container, as the case may be; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the exercise of his duties as a public officer.

section.name: s16B
section.heading: Powers of arrest of authorized officers

subsection.content: An authorized officer may, subject to subsection (2), arrest or detain for further enquiries without warrant any person whom he reasonably suspects of having committed any offence under this Ordinance.

content.leadIn: An authorized officer who arrests any person under subsection (1) shall forthwith take the person to a police station or, if further enquiries are necessary, first to an office of the Customs and Excise Department and then to a police station, there to be dealt with in accordance with the provisions of the Police Force Ordinance (Cap. 232):
content.proviso: Provided that in no case shall any person be detained for more than 48 hours without being charged and brought before a magistrate.

subsection.content: If any person forcibly resists or attempts to evade arrest under this section, the authorized officer may use such force as is reasonably necessary to effect the arrest.
The Commissioner may issue guidelines on matters in relation to which an authorized officer may exercise powers under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1), the guidelines may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: indicate the manner in which powers will be exercised by authorized officers with respect to the matters to which the guidelines relate; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provide guidance on the operation of any provision of this Ordinance relating to those matters.

subsection.content: Guidelines may be published in any manner that the Commissioner considers appropriate.
Guidelines are not subsidiary legislation.
The Commissioner may amend or revoke any guidelines. Subsections (3) and (4) apply to an amendment or revocation of guidelines in the same way as they apply to the guidelines.
Before issuing any guidelines or amendments of guidelines, the Commissioner must consult any persons that the Commissioner considers appropriate.
The Commissioner must make copies of all guidelines and amendments of guidelines available to the public for inspection at the Commissioner’s office during ordinary business hours.

subsection.leadIn: A person does not incur any civil or criminal liability only because the person has contravened any of the guidelines. If, in any legal proceedings, a court is satisfied that a guideline is relevant to determining a matter that is in issue—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the guideline is admissible in evidence in the proceedings; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: proof that the person contravened or did not contravene the guideline may be relied on by any party to the proceedings as tending to establish or negate the matter.

subsection.content: Where goods seized or detained under section 15 are, or are reasonably suspected by the Commissioner to be, goods to which a forged trade mark is applied, or to which a trade mark or mark so nearly resembling a trade mark as to be calculated to deceive is falsely applied, the Commissioner shall, wherever reasonably practicable, notify the owner of the trade mark or his authorized agent of the seizure or detention, as the case may be. (Amended 35 of 2000 s. 98)

subsection.leadIn: In the circumstances specified in subsection (1), the Commissioner may disclose to the owner of the trade mark or to his authorized agent— (Amended 35 of 2000 s. 98)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the time, and the address of the place, of seizure or detention of the goods;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the name and address of the person from whom the goods have been seized or detained;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the nature and quantity of the goods seized or detained;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any statement made to the Commissioner by any person in connection with the seizure or detention, either with the prior consent in writing of that person or without such consent where that person is dead or cannot after reasonable enquiries by the Commissioner as to his whereabouts be found by the Commissioner;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: any other information or document relating to the goods seized or detained which the Commissioner thinks fit to disclose.

subsection.leadIn: The owner of a trade mark or his authorized agent— (Amended 35 of 2000 s. 98)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where he seeks disclosure of any information or document that is not referred to in subsection (2); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where information or a document that is referred to in subsection (2) is not disclosed by the Commissioner,

subsection.continued: may apply to the Court of First Instance for an order requiring the Commissioner to disclose such information or document and the Court of First Instance may on such an application make such order for disclosure as it deems fit. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.content: An application under subsection (3) may be begun by motion with previous notice to the Commissioner.

section.name: s16D
section.heading: International co-operation
section.content: The Commissioner may, for the purpose of promoting international co-operation in the protection of intellectual property rights, disclose information obtained in pursuance of this Ordinance to the customs authorities of any Convention country.

section.name: s16E
section.heading: Enforcement relating to telecommunications and broadcasting

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), the Communications Authority may exercise any of the powers conferred on an authorized officer under this Ordinance (other than Part 3A).
The Chief Executive in Council may, by notice published in the Gazette, specify powers covered by subsection (1) that are not exercisable by the Communications Authority.

The Communications Authority, or any public officer authorized in writing in that behalf by that Authority, may exercise any of the powers that by virtue of this section are exercisable by that Authority but may only do so in relation to any commercial practices of licensees under the Telecommunications Ordinance (Cap. 106) or the Broadcasting Ordinance (Cap. 562) that are directly connected with the provision of a telecommunications service or broadcasting service under the relevant Ordinance.
Nothing in this section enables the exercise of powers with respect to any conduct covered by section 9 or 12.

The fact that a power is exercisable in relation to a commercial practice by the Communications Authority or any public officer authorized in writing by that Authority does not, subject to section 16F, prevent that power being exercised in relation to that practice by the Commissioner or an authorized officer.

To avoid doubt, in exercising a power under this Ordinance the Communications Authority or any public officer authorized in writing by that Authority does not do so as an agent or delegate of the Commissioner.

section.name: s16F
section.heading: Transfer of matters between enforcement bodies

subsection.content: If the Commissioner or the Communications Authority is performing a function under this Ordinance in relation to a matter over which the other has concurrent jurisdiction, the 2 bodies may agree that the matter be transferred to and be dealt with by one of them.

Unless there is an agreement as mentioned in subsection (1), if the Commissioner or the Communications Authority is performing or has performed a function under this Ordinance in relation to a matter over which the other has concurrent jurisdiction, the other must not perform any function in relation to that matter.
The Commissioner and the Communications Authority must prepare and sign a memorandum of understanding for the purpose of co-ordinating the performance of their functions under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1), a memorandum of understanding may provide for any or all of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the manner in which the parties will perform the functions that they have jurisdiction to perform concurrently under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the manner in which the parties will resolve any dispute between themselves;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the provision of assistance by one party to the other;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the allocation between the parties of responsibility for particular matters or classes of matters;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: arrangements for the supply by one party to the other of information relating to a matter over which they have concurrent jurisdiction;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: arrangements for keeping the other party informed about progress when one party is performing functions that may be performed concurrently under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the joint authorship of educational material or guidelines on matters over which the parties have concurrent jurisdiction.

subsection.content: The parties to a memorandum of understanding may amend or replace any memorandum of understanding prepared and signed under this section.

The parties to a memorandum of understanding must, within 6 weeks after the memorandum or any amendment of the memorandum is signed by both parties, publish it in any manner the parties consider appropriate.

The Commissioner and the Communications Authority must prepare and sign their first memorandum of understanding under this section as soon as is reasonably practicable after the coming into operation of section 27 of the Trade Descriptions (Unfair Trade Practices) (Amendment) Ordinance 2012 (25 of 2012).

The Communications Authority, or the Communications Authority jointly with the Commissioner, may issue guidelines on matters in relation to which the Communications Authority or any public officer authorized in writing by that Authority may exercise powers under section 16E(3).

subsection.leadIn: Subsections (2) to (6) and (8) of section 16BA apply to guidelines issued under this section in the same way as they apply to guidelines issued under that section. For this purpose—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the reference in subsection (2)(a) of that section to authorized officers is to be taken to be a reference to the Communications Authority or any public officer authorized in writing by that Authority to exercise any of the powers that by virtue of section 16E are exercisable by that Authority; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any reference in subsection (3), (5) or (6) of that section to the Commissioner is to be taken to be a reference to the Communications Authority, or the Communications Authority jointly with the Commissioner, as the case requires.

subsection.content: The Communications Authority or, in the case of jointly issued guidelines, both the Communications Authority and the Commissioner must make copies of all guidelines and amendments of guidelines available to the public for inspection at their office during ordinary business hours.

section.name: s16I
section.heading: Transitional provision
section.content: Subject to section 43 of the Telecommunications Ordinance (Cap. 106), anything that was done under that Ordinance as in force immediately before the commencement date* as defined by subsection (1) of that section and that was in effect immediately before that date continues, in so far as it may be done under this Ordinance, to have effect as if it had been done under this Ordinance.

section.name: s17
section.heading: Offences of obstruction and disclosure of information

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to any other Ordinance, any person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: wilfully obstructs an authorized officer in the exercise of his powers or the performance of his duties under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: wilfully fails to comply with any requirement properly made to him by any such authorized officer; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: without reasonable excuse fails to give such authorized officer any other assistance or information which the authorized officer may reasonably require of him for the purpose of the performance of the officer’s functions under this Ordinance, (Amended L.N. 65 of 1986)

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2A), any person who discloses to any other person— (Amended 2 of 1987 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any information with respect to any manufacturing process or trade secret obtained by him in premises which he has entered by virtue of this Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any information obtained by him in pursuance of this Ordinance,

subsection.continued: commits an offence unless the disclosure was made—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: in or for the purpose of the performance by him or any other person of functions under this Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: in the case of paragraph (b) under the direction or order of a court.

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.leadIn: A person does not commit an offence under subsection (2) by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: disclosing information under section 16C(1) or (2) or under an order of the Court of First Instance made under section 16C(3);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: disclosing information under section 16D; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: disclosing information under section 30F(1) or under an order of the Court of First Instance made under section 30F(2). (Replaced 11 of 1996 s. 15. Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.content: Any person who, in giving any such information as is referred to in subsection (1)(c), makes any statement which he knows to be false commits an offence.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (5), nothing in this section shall be taken to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: require a person to answer any question or give any information if to do so might incriminate that person or the wife or husband of that person; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: compel the production by a solicitor of a document containing a privileged communication made by or to him in that capacity or authorize the seizure of any such document in his possession.

subsection.leadIn: A person shall not be excused, by reason that to do so may incriminate that person or the wife or husband of that person of an offence under this Ordinance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: from answering any question put to that person in any civil proceedings;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: from complying with any order made in any such proceedings,

subsection.continued: but no statement or admission made by a person in answering a question put or complying with an order made shall, in proceedings for an offence under this Ordinance, be admissible in evidence against that person or (unless they married after the making of the statement or admission) against the wife or husband of that person. (Amended L.N. 123 of 1982)

subsection.leadIn: Any person who commits an offence under section 4, 5, 7, 7A, 9, 12, 13E, 13F, 13G, 13H or 13I shall be liable— (Amended 65 of 2000 s. 3; 19 of 2008 s. 8; 25 of 2012 s. 14)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment, to a fine of $500,000 and to imprisonment for 5 years; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction, to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: Any person who commits an offence under section 16A(3) shall be liable to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 3 months. (Added 2 of 1987 s. 4)
Any person who commits an offence under section 17 shall be liable to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 1 year.

If a person is convicted of an offence under section 4, 5, 7, 7A, 13E, 13F, 13G, 13H or 13I, the court may, in addition to passing any sentence that may otherwise be passed by law, order the person to pay an amount of compensation that it thinks reasonable to any person who has suffered financial loss resulting from that offence.
An amount of compensation ordered to be paid to a person under subsection (1) is recoverable as a civil debt.

section.name: s19
section.heading: Time limit for prosecutions
section.leadIn: No prosecution for an offence under this Ordinance shall be brought after—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the expiration of 3 years from the date of commission of the offence; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the expiration of 1 year from the date of discovery of the offence by the prosecutor,

subsection.content: If an offence under this Ordinance is committed by a body corporate or by a person as a member of an unincorporated body, and it is proved that the offence has been committed with the consent or connivance or is attributable to the neglect of a person specified in subsection (2), that person also commits the offence and is liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly.

subsection.leadIn: The person referred to in subsection (1) is a person who, at the time of the offence, was—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: (in the case of a body corporate) a director, shadow director, company secretary, principal officer or manager of the body corporate;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: (in the case of a member of an unincorporated body) a partner or office holder in or a member or manager of the unincorporated body; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: (in either case mentioned in paragraph (a) or (b)) purporting to act in the capacity of a person referred to in that paragraph.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: company secretary (公司秘書) includes any person occupying the position of company secretary, by whatever name called;

def.name: PrincipalOfficer
def.leadIn: principal officer (主要人員), in relation to a body corporate, means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person employed or engaged by the body corporate who, either alone or jointly with one or more other persons, is responsible under the immediate authority of the directors of the body corporate for the conduct of the business of the body corporate; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person employed or engaged by the body corporate who, under the immediate authority of a director of the body corporate or a person to whom paragraph (a) applies, exercises managerial functions in respect of the body corporate;

subsection.def: shadow director (幕後董事), in relation to a body corporate, means a person in accordance with whose directions or instructions (excluding advice given in a professional capacity) the directors, or a majority of the directors, of the body corporate are accustomed to act.

section.name: s21
section.heading: Offences due to fault of other person

subsection.content: Where the commission by any person of an offence under this Ordinance is due to the act or default of some other person, that other person shall be guilty of the offence, and a person may be charged with and convicted of the offence by virtue of this section whether or not proceedings are taken against the first-mentioned person. (Amended 25 of 2012 s. 16)
In subsection (1) the reference to some other person does not include an exempt person in the case of an offence under section 7A, 13E, 13F, 13G, 13H or 13I. (Added 25 of 2012 s. 16)

section.name: s21A
section.heading: Extra-territoriality
section.content: A trader may commit an offence under this Ordinance with respect to a commercial practice even if the practice is directed to consumers who are outside Hong Kong if, at the time of engaging in the practice, the trader is in Hong Kong or Hong Kong is the trader’s usual place of business.

section.name: s22
section.heading: Accessory to offences committed outside Hong Kong
section.content: Subject to the provisions of this Ordinance, any person who, in Hong Kong, procures, counsels, aids, abets or is accessory to the commission outside Hong Kong of an act which, if committed in Hong Kong, would be an offence under this Ordinance, commits that offence as a principal and shall be liable to be prosecuted in Hong Kong as if the offence had been committed within Hong Kong.

subsection.content: Where any act or omission constitutes both an offence under this Ordinance and an offence under the Public Health and Municipal Services Ordinance (Cap. 132), evidence on behalf of the prosecution concerning any sample procured for analysis shall be admissible in proceedings in respect of the offence under this Ordinance if, but only if, the provisions of section 63 of the Public Health and Municipal Services Ordinance (Cap. 132) have been complied with. (Amended 10 of 1986 s. 32)

The Chief Executive in Council may by regulations provide that in any proceedings for an offence under this Ordinance in relation to such goods as may be specified in the regulations (other than proceedings for an offence referred to in subsection (1)) evidence on behalf of the prosecution concerning any sample procured for analysis shall not be admissible unless the sample has been dealt with in such manner as may be specified in the regulations. (Amended 65 of 2000 s. 3)

The Chief Executive in Council may by regulations provide that certificates issued by such persons as may be specified by the regulations in relation to such matters as may be so specified shall, subject to this section, be received in evidence of those matters in any proceedings under this Ordinance. (Amended 65 of 2000 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: Such a certificate shall not be received in evidence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: unless the party against whom it is to be given in evidence has been served with a copy thereof not less than 7 days before the hearing; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if that party has, not less than 3 days before the hearing served on the other party a notice requiring the attendance of the person issuing the certificate.

subsection.content: For the purposes of this section any document purporting to be such a certificate as is referred to in this section shall be deemed to be such a certificate unless the contrary is shown.

section.name: s24A
section.heading: Rule of evidence regarding imported goods

subsection.content: In any prosecution for an offence under this Ordinance in respect of the import of goods to which a false trade description of the place of manufacture, production, processing or reconditioning is applied, evidence that the goods were imported from a place shall be prima facie evidence that the goods were manufactured, produced, processed or reconditioned, as the case may be, in such place. (Amended 9 of 2005 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: Notwithstanding subsection (1), in any prosecution for an offence referred to in that subsection, a trade description which indicates that the goods were manufactured, produced, processed or reconditioned in a place shall not be regarded as false only because of the evidence that the goods were imported from another place, if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that other place is located within the first-mentioned place; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the first-mentioned place is located within that other place. (Added 9 of 2005 s. 3)

section.name: s25
section.heading: Description of trade mark in pleading
section.content: In any information, indictment, pleading, proceeding or document in which any trade mark or forged trade mark is intended to be mentioned, it shall be sufficient, without further description and without any copy or facsimile, to state that trade mark or forged trade mark to be a trade mark or forged trade mark.

subsection.leadIn: In any proceedings for an offence under this Ordinance, the person charged is, subject to subsection (2), entitled to be acquitted if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: sufficient evidence is adduced to raise an issue that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: the commission of the offence was due to—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: a mistake;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: reliance on information supplied to the person charged by another person;

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: the act or default of another person;

subparagraph.name: D
subparagraph.content: an accident; or

subparagraph.name: E
subparagraph.content: some other cause beyond the control of the person charged; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.leadIn: the person charged took all reasonable precautions and exercised all due diligence to avoid the commission of the offence by—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: the person charged; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: any person under the control of the person charged; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the contrary is not proved by the prosecution beyond reasonable doubt. (Replaced 18 of 2014 s. 53)

subsection.content: If in any case the issue raised under subsection (1)(a) involves the allegation that the commission of the offence was due to the act or default of another person or to reliance on information supplied by another person, the person charged shall not, without leave of the court, be entitled to rely on that issue unless, within a period ending 7 clear days before the hearing, the person charged has served on the prosecutor a notice in writing giving such information identifying or assisting in the identification of that other person as was then in the possession of the person charged. (Amended 18 of 2014 s. 53)

section.name: s26AA
section.heading: Additional defence (supply of goods or service to which false trade description is applied etc.)
section.leadIn: Without limiting section 26, in any proceedings for an offence under section 7(1)(a)(ii) or (b) or 7A(1)(b), the person charged is entitled to be acquitted if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: sufficient evidence is adduced to raise an issue that the person charged—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: did not know;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: had no reason to suspect; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: could not with reasonable diligence have ascertained,

paragraph.continued: that the goods or service did not conform to the trade description, or that the trade description had been applied to the goods or service; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the contrary is not proved by the prosecution beyond reasonable doubt.

section.name: s26AAB
section.heading: Additional defence (sale of goods to which forged trade mark is applied etc.)
section.leadIn: Without limiting section 26, in any proceedings for an offence under section 9(2), the person charged is entitled to be acquitted if—

paragraph.name: a
